Shift in Chinese retailers' strategy risks entrenching deflationA shift in Chinese retailers' strategy toward lower-priced goods and services to win cost-conscious consumers risks embedding the country's recent deflationary trends more permanently into the world's second-largest economy. New US rule targeting real estate money laundering reaches White House reviewA long-awaited U.S. rule aimed at curbing money laundering in real estate has reached a key White House office for review, the final hurdle for it to clear before it can be formally proposed next year. Swiss bankers open to talks on some of measures demanded by country's regulatorThe Swiss Bankers Association (SBA) on Tuesday said it is open to discussions on a possible senior management regime for the country's lenders, one of the new measures demanded by Swiss regulator FINMA following the crash of Credit Suisse. Australia court finds Melbourne man guilty of foreign interferenceAn Australia court on Tuesday found a Melbourne man who held prominent positions in Chinese community associations guilty of planning an act of foreign interference, the first verdict of its kind under a law introduced in 2018. Investors dumped cash, bought stocks in December - BofAInvestors turned more bullish in December, buying stocks and reducing cash holdings on expectations the U.S. Federal Reserve has finished hiking rates and the global economy will avoid a big recession, a BofA fund manager survey showed on Tuesday. Not so sweet: India may need to import sugar as planting wanesIndia's sugar output this crop year, hit by weak rains, is set to lag consumption for the first time in seven years, according to traders and a survey of farmers, and lower plantings may even force the world's No.2 producer to import in the following year. Tue, 19 Dec 2023 06:39:44 GMT NPNV4EOAGFNXJAFMRLLDDEL3BI https://www.reuters.com/markets/commodities/not-so-sweet-india-may-need-import-sugar-planting-wanes-2023-12-19/Rajendra Jadhav市场商品
China Sinochem buys rare Venezuelan oil cargo after U.S. suspends sanctions -sourcesChina's Sinochem Corp has bought a million barrels of Venezuelan crude oil for arrival in December, a rare purchase as the state oil and chemicals group capitalises on Washington's suspension of sanctions on the South American producer.
